page.title: 05Aythorpe Roding Mill
page.content: The mill was built in 1760,then the brick bottom was not there. The whole windmill was held up by a massive pole. The windmill is the oldest one of its kind. Now the bottom is round, made of brick and is called a Round House. Something called the "Boss" holds the sails together in the middle. There is a lightning conductor on the end of all the sails. A spider cuffing opens and closes the shutters on the sails which are 64 feet long. The round house is only for protection to the quarter bars, cross bars and of course the main bar. There is a massive brake which stops the sails. The flour drops onto a kind of propellor and is sorted into best flour, second best flour and bran, where once again it drops down, this time to different bins and is shovelled into sacks and sold.
